title: 108_s73
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Center for Social Work Research Act". The findings of Congress highlight the role of social workers in improving individual and family functioning, providing prevention and treatment services in various areas, and offering valuable research on social concerns from an interdisciplinary approach. Establishment of National Center for Social Work Research under Section 401(b)(2) of the Public Health Service Act to enhance research on social concerns and interdisciplinary approaches. The National Center for Social Work Research conducts and supports targeted research on social work methods and outcomes related to significant social issues. It aims to promote research and training to inform social work practices and provide policymakers with research information to better understand complex social issues and make informed funding decisions. The Director of the National Center for Social Work Research may provide research training, fellowships, and stipends to individuals studying the prevention of disease, health promotion, social work care, child abuse, neglect, and youth violence in underserved populations and areas. The Director of the Center may provide grants to nonprofit institutions for training, instruction, and fellowships with stipends and allowances as determined necessary. The Director of the Center may provide grants to nonprofit institutions for training, instruction, and fellowships with stipends and allowances as determined necessary. SEC. 485L. ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Secretary shall establish an advisory council for the Center to advise on activities, accept gifts, and make research recommendations. The Center may review research applications, recommend projects for approval, and review grants and agreements. It can collect information on studies and make it available through publications with the Director's approval. The advisory council appointed by the Secretary includes ex officio members such as the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Director of NIH, and the Chief Social Work Officer of the Veterans' Administration. The council may appoint subcommittees, convene workshops, and have up to 18 individuals appointed by the Secretary. The advisory council appointed by the Secretary includes key officials from various government departments and agencies, along with additional members as deemed necessary. The Secretary appoints up to 18 individuals to the council to effectively carry out its functions. The Secretary appoints up to 18 individuals to the advisory council, with two-thirds from health and scientific disciplines and one-third from the general public, including leaders in public policy and law. At least 7 members must be professional social workers. The Secretary appoints up to 18 individuals to the advisory council, ensuring staggered terms. Members do not receive compensation if they are US officers or employees. Other members receive compensation not exceeding GS-18 rates for each day of service. The term of office for advisory council members appointed under subsection (b)(3) is 4 years, with the possibility of serving until a successor is appointed. Reappointments are not allowed within 2 years of the prior term's expiration. Vacancies must be filled within 90 days by the Secretary. The chairperson of the advisory council is selected by the Secretary from among the members appointed under subsection (b)(3) and serves a 2-year term. The council must meet at least 3 times each fiscal year, with meeting locations subject to the Director of the Center's approval. The Director designates a staff member as the executive secretary of the council. The Director of the Center provides staff and assistance to the advisory council. New members receive orientation and training for effective participation. The advisory council can make comments and recommendations in the biennial report regarding its activities, the Center's progress, and future directions. The advisory council may prepare additional reports as deemed appropriate. The Director of the Center, in consultation with the advisory council, prepares a biennial report for inclusion in the overall report, detailing the Center's activities and program policies. Additional reports may be prepared as needed. A quarterly report is also submitted to Congress, summarizing research findings and policy implications.
